title: Siddartha
author: Hermann Hesse
review: One of the best books form my favourite author [[highlight: Hermann Hesse]] which explores intelligence and search for wisdom. I began this book thinking it's the story of the Buddha, but it's an alternative story of another man named Siddartha. The Buddha appears in the story and I found that cameo very cinematic. I like how this book challenges the teachings of Buddha in a very constructive way. And I liked how it made me question deeper, as opposed to what is taught in Buddhism as a reliogion, where speculation is a sin. This builds on top of how Buddha approached Buddhism as a lifestyle and a philosophy instead of a religion.

title: White Nights
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
review: Relatable story of a man with too much active imagination. Shares the same message and themes with [[highlight: 500 Days of Summer]].

title: The Richest Man in Babylon
author: George S. Clason
review: A very dumbed down story-telling approach to financial literacy. Deeply resonated with me compared to [[highlight: Rich Dad Poor Dad]]. I like the simple examples and analogies it uses to teach good financial principles. Recommended starting point for anyone looking to manage personal finances better.

title: The Three-Body Problem
author: Cixin Liu
review: Reading this book was so much better than watching the Netflix series. Sad that they have removed most of the science stuff and dumbed it down for general people to understand. The book covers more theoretical foundation and history of the Trisolarians. My favourite scene from the book is where the sophons are unravelled into larger dimensional space, in which the experiments go wrong and a large eye in the sky nearly destroys the trisolarians.

title: No Longer Human
author: Osamu Dazai
review: Very depressing book. Narrates tragical events of a man who hates himself. Explores the extreme ends of self-destruction.

title: The Glass Bead Game
author: Hermann Hesse
review: Complicated book but my favourite so far. From my favourite author as well. A bit lengthy and the wording is hard to comphrehend. Only for seasoned readers. It's a mystical vibe in a sense since the true 'how to play' of the Glass Bead Game is never mentioned.

title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Ray Bradbury
review: Set in a dystopian future (or an alternate timeline) with steam-punk (?) aesthetics. The core theme of [[highlight:man's search for meaning and wisdom]] is there and I love it. These types of themes open up many views about the world and different interpretations so I believe it's important to read them.
